data.title: The American Version of the Love Actually Sequel Has a Surprise Twist
data.meta_description: So this is why Laura Linney wasn’t featured in the British version. . .
data.text:
Plot twist: There will be two versions of the Love Actually sequel, actually. Though the first 10-minute sequel premiered on Red Nose Day in the U.K. on Friday, Entertainment Weekly has revealed that the version premiering in the U.S. on May 25 on NBC will have one slight twist: it will also feature Laura Linney.

“I’d done something for the last Red Nose Day,” the actress tells EW. “So I’d kept in touch with [Love Actually director] Richard Curtis. And then he sent me an e-mail, explaining this short film reunion. I said yes, obviously. How could I say no? And right away we were figuring out our schedules.”

In the original 2003 film, Linney plays the kindhearted Sarah, an American working at a graphic design company in London and taking care of her mentally ill brother. She also falls in love with her boss, Michael (played by Rodrigo Santoro).

The actress will film her sequel scene in April but tells EW she has “no idea what I’m doing yet. Not a clue.”

We shan’t spoil what happens in the Love Actually sequel, but there were many tidbits from it that took the Internet by storm—like a clip of the once and future prime minister (Hugh Grant) dancing to Drake’s Hotline Bling, and a surprise cameo from supermodel Kate Moss.

The short manages to answer everyone‘s questions about everything that happened to the beloved characters. Did Juliet (Keira Knightley) and Mark (Andrew Lincoln) ever get together? Did the rebellious Billy Mack (Bill Nighy) find inner peace? Is Rufus (Rowan Atkinson) still wrapping gifts with absurd pomp and circumstance? We hope so—though U.K. fans and web-savvy Americans already know. Soon we’ll learn the romantic fates of Sarah and Michael, too.
